channel.title: Comments on: Test-Driving Backbone Views With JQuery Templates, The Jasmine Gem, and Jasmine-JQuery

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: i've used symbolic links for this, as well. it works well in *nix based systems (osx, linux, etc). when sharing code with windows users, though, they have to set up the link with a tool that doesn't come directly with windows. tradeoffs... but it's definitely a good option
item.content:encoded: i’ve used symbolic links for this, as well. it works well in *nix based systems (osx, linux, etc). when sharing code with windows users, though, they have to set up the link with a tool that doesn’t come directly with windows. tradeoffs… but it’s definitely a good option

item.title: By: Jason
item.dc:creator: Jason
item.description: You might want to update the reference to .call() as it is now .bind().
item.content:encoded: You might want to update the reference to .call() as it is now .bind().

item.title: By: Anonymous
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
item.description: Not sure loading fixtures would work when using rake jasmine and MVC: since rake jasmine uses WEBrick and ASP.NET MVC another server, you'll get a cross-origin error when attempting to load the MVC fixture. I suppose there is a way around it though, need to have a look at it.
item.content:encoded:
Not sure loading fixtures would work when using rake jasmine and MVC: since rake jasmine uses WEBrick and ASP.NET MVC another server, you’ll get a cross-origin error when attempting to load the MVC fixture.
I suppose there is a way around it though, need to have a look at it.

item.title: By: Derick Bailey
item.dc:creator: Derick Bailey
item.description: nice! my solution well in sinatra, but i can see how this would be better if you're in rails 3.1. thanks for the info! i'll definitely look into this when i get on to a rails 3.1 project :)
item.content:encoded: nice! my solution well in sinatra, but i can see how this would be better if you’re in rails 3.1. thanks for the info! i’ll definitely look into this when i get on to a rails 3.1 project :)

item.title: By: Tim Oxley
item.dc:creator: Tim Oxley
item.content:encoded:
I tried this method of importing templates as fixtures, but didn’t really like it. Another avenue for template loading which I prefer, is to use Sprockets from Rails 3.1.

Sprockets (https://github.com/sstephenson/sprockets) has specific handling for javascript templates. To use your template ‘partials’ in your tests just require the template and use the JST array:

//= require templates/my_template
$(“#content”).html(JST["templates/my_template"](someDatas));

…which is also the exact same way you require and utilize templates in your production JS code. It also feels nice and clean.

Also, I wanted to use Handlebars as my template language of choice and thus required a Handlebars engine to Rails 3.1: https://github.com/leshill/handlebars_assets

item.title: By: Dave Ward
item.dc:creator: Dave Ward
item.description:
Re: template loading, you might be interested in this followup post to the one you linked, if you haven't seen it: http://encosia.com/jquery-templates-composite-rendering-and-remote-loading/
That way you minimize the number of HTTP requests necessary to pull down logically related groups of templates, but you also don't have to burden the initial page load with templates that aren't used immediately. Of course, for templates that *are* used immediately as the page loads, I agree that it does make sense to go ahead and embed those in the view.
item.content:encoded:
Re: template loading, you might be interested in this followup post to the one you linked, if you haven’t seen it: http://encosia.com/jquery-templates-composite-rendering-and-remote-loading/

That way you minimize the number of HTTP requests necessary to pull down logically related groups of templates, but you also don’t have to burden the initial page load with templates that aren’t used immediately. Of course, for templates that *are* used immediately as the page loads, I agree that it does make sense to go ahead and embed those in the view.

item.title: By: Anonymous
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
item.description: http://lostechies.com/johnteague/2010/06/28/unit-testing-your-mvc-views-with-qunit/ if you ever need to do it in MVC. It's a bit old school now and should be easier with the newer view engines.
item.content:encoded: http://lostechies.com/johnteague/2010/06/28/unit-testing-your-mvc-views-with-qunit/ if you ever need to do it in MVC.  It’s a bit old school now and should be easier with the newer view engines.
